A week ago I was tinkering with deriving normativity from systems theoretic principles, and landed on the following insight:

> Evil is a self-maintaining system that not only harms but reproduces the representational projections that make the harm non-legible.

Feeling pretty vindicated rn.

reply_context.text:
I found that this is wrong. Democracy actually is a powerful motivating force for a critical slice of the population *if they perceive a real threat*.

I call this the "legibility" theory of democratic backsliding: the more legible the threat, the more likely it is to prompt effective pushback.

posts.text:
So if hill (H) valley (V) is a clock pulse, this procedure changes the signal from 
HVHVHVHVHVHV to 
HVVHHVVHHVVH

which decomposes to an octave above plus an octave below the original frequency. Next step is noticing that the rectified signal (HVHV -> HHHH) gives you an octave above.

reply_context.text: There's a way you can construct this that doesn't look the same as if you do it analytically, but which I think imparts a really strong intuition for what's going on. Treat the sine wave as a clock signal that flips an inverter on/off at each clock pulse.

posts.text: There's a way you can construct this that doesn't look the same as if you do it analytically, but which I think imparts a really strong intuition for what's going on. Treat the sine wave as a clock signal that flips an inverter on/off at each clock pulse.
